o: A standard awareness document representing 10 most critical web application security risks

q: What is the #1 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A01: Broken Access Control (moved up from #5)
Users can access data/functionality outside their intended permissions (e.g. user viewing admin page)
Insecure Direct Object Reference (e.g. changing `id=123` to `id=124` to view another user's profile). A type of Broken Access Control
Principle of Least Privilege. Users should only have access absolutely necessary for their job

q: What is the #2 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A02: Cryptographic Failures (previously Sensitive Data Exposure)
Using weak algorithms (MD5), hardcoded keys, transmitting data in clear text (HTTP), or not encrypting data at rest
No. It is fast and vulnerable to collisions/rainbow tables. Use Argon2/Bcrypt
Random data added to password before hashing to defend against Rainbow Tables

q: What is the #3 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A03: Injection (Includes SQLi, XSS, Command Injection)
Untrusted data is sent to an interpreter (SQL, OS Shell) as part of a command, tricking it to execute unintended commands

q: What is the #4 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A04: Insecure Design (New category for 2021). Focuses on risks related to design flaws (missing control) vs implementation bugs
Identifying potential threats/vulnerabilities during the DESIGN phase, before code is written

q: What is the #5 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A05: Security Misconfiguration (Includes old XML External Entities XXE now)
Default accounts/passwords, unnecessary features enabled, detailed error messages active in prod, missing headers
XML External Entities. Attack against XML parsers leading to file disclosure (reading /etc/passwd) or SSRF

q: What is the #6 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?

o: To patch known CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) in libraries like Log4j, OpenSSL, etc
Software Composition Analysis. Scans `package.json`/`pom.xml` for known vulnerable dependencies (e.g. Snyk, Dependabot)

q: What is the #7 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A07: Identification and Authentication Failures (formerly Broken Authentication)
Weak passwords, missing 2FA/MFA, session fixation, permitting credential stuffing
Automated injection of breached username/password pairs to gain access to accounts

q: What is the #8 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A08: Software and Data Integrity Failures (New). Includes insecure deserialization and CI/CD pipeline integrity
Restoring data from a file/stream (e.g. JSON/Java Object) without validation, allowing execution of malicious code inside the object

q: What is the #9 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?
o: A09: Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
Attackers can breach system and persist for months without detection if logs are missing or ignored

q: What is the #10 risk in OWASP Top 10 (2021)?

o: Attacker forces server to make a request to an internal-only resource (e.g. cloud metadata service, internal db)
Accessing `http://169.254.169.254` via SSRF to steal AWS/Cloud credentials from the running instance
Dynamic Application Security Testing. Testing running app from outside (black-box)
Static Application Security Testing. Analyzing source code for vulnerabilities (white-box)
Interactive Application Security Testing. Agents inside running app analyze code execution during tests
Trick user into clicking something invisible (iframe) while they think they are clicking innocuous page
HTTP Strict Transport Security. Header forcing browser to only connect via HTTPS (prevents downgrade attacks)
Man-In-The-Middle. Attacker intercepts traffic between user and server
Yes, if certificates are valid and protocol is secure (TLS 1.2/1.3)
Attacker sets a user's session ID (via link) before they login. After login, attacker uses that known ID to hijack session
Regenerate Session ID upon successful login
Accessing files outside web root using `../` (e.g. `../../etc/passwd`)
User accessing data of another user with SAME permission level (Peer)
User accessing functionality of HIGHER permission level (User becomes Admin)
Binding HTTP parameters directly to objects/models without filtering. Attacker sends `{ isAdmin: true }` in body to elevate privs
Use DTOs (Data Transfer Objects) or strict whitelist of allowed fields
Resending a valid captured data transmission (e.g. API call) to repeat the action
Use Nonce (Number used once) or Timestamp in signed requests
Random number/string used only once to ensure uniqueness/freshness
Crypto attack using error messages about padding validation to decrypt ciphertext (e.g. POODLE)
Precomputed table of hash chains for reversing cryptographic hash functions (cracking passwords)
Vulnerability known to attacker but not vendor (0 days since public awareness)
Manipulating people into performing actions or divulging confidential info (Phishing, Vishing)
Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive info (passwords, credit cards) by disguising as trustworthy entity in email
Phishing targeted at a specific individual or organization
Web Application Firewall. Filters HTTP traffic to block common attacks (SQLi, XSS) before hitting app
No. It is a mitigation layer. WAFs can be bypassed. Root cause must be fixed in code
Runtime Application Self-Protection. Security tech built/linked into the app runtime to detect attacks in real-time
Attacker inputs newlines/control characters into logs to forge log entries or confuse parsers
Sanitize input before logging (replace CRLF with space)
Restricting number of requests a user can make in time window. Prevents Brute Force/DoS
Denial of Service. Rendering a resource unavailable to intended users
Distributed Denial of Service. DoS from multiple sources (botnet)
DoS attack keeping many connections open to server by sending partial HTTP requests slowly
Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart. Prevent bots
Checking if input meets criteria (type, length, format, range) BEFORE processing
Cleaning input by removing/replacing dangerous characters

q: Which is better: Whitelisting or Blacklisting?
o: Whitelisting (Allow only known good) is strictly safer than Blacklisting (Block known bad)
Converting data into safe form for specific interpreter (HTML entity encoding preventing XSS)
Cookie flag preventing JavaScript (`document.cookie`) from accessing the cookie. Mitigates XSS token theft
Cookie flag controlling when cookies are sent with cross-site requests. Mitigates CSRF
Ensures cookie is only sent over encrypted (HTTPS) connections
Hardcoded list in browsers of domains that must ALWAYS be HTTPS. Protects first visit
HTTP Public Key Pinning. Removed due to risk of suicide (bricking domain if key lost)
Content Security Policy. Header to restrict sources of content (scripts, images) browser handles. Mitigates XSS
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. Mechanism allowing server to permit browser to load resources from other origin
JSON Web Token. Compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties
Part of JWT ensuring integrity. Created using header, payload, and secret

q: What is the 'None' algorithm attack in JWT?
o: Attacker strips signature and sets `alg: none`. Server blindly accepts token without verifying signature
Hardcoding secrets in source code committed to git. Use ENV variables or Vault
Fake credential/data planted to detect breach. If used, it triggers alarm
Layered security approach. (WAF + Input Valid + Param Query + Output Encode + Logging)

q: What is 'Checking left at the door' approach?
o: Perimeter security only (firewall). Once inside, everything is trusted. (Bad practice - see Zero Trust)
Never trust, always verify. Every request (even internal) must be authenticated and authorized
Integrating security checks (SAST/SCA) early in dev lifecycle (commit/design) rather than just before deploy
Crowdsourcing security testing by offering rewards for reporting valid vulnerabilities
Simulated cyberattack against your computer system to check for exploitable vulnerabilities
Full-scope multi-layered attack simulation (Social Eng, Physical, Network) to test organization's detection/response
Defensive security team responsible for maintaining defenses and responding to incidents
Collaborative effort where Red and Blue teams work together to improve detection/defense
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures. A list of publicly disclosed computer security flaws
Common Vulnerability Scoring System. Standard for assessing severity of vulnerabilities (0.0 to 10.0)
Code or technique that takes advantage of a vulnerability to cause unintended behavior
The malicious code executed by the exploit (e.g. reverse shell, dropping malware)
Target machine initiates connection back to attacker (bypassing inbound firewall rules), giving attacker shell access
Attacker connects to a port opened on target machine (often blocked by firewall)
Script (PHP, JSP, ASPX) uploaded to web server allowing remote command execution via HTTP requests
Allowing users to upload files without validation (name, type, content), leading to RCE (Remote Code Exec)

q: How to prevent File Upload attacks?
o: Validate file type (extension AND magic bytes), rename file (UUID), store outside web root, use virus scanner
First few bytes of a file that identify its format (e.g. `FF D8 FF` for JPEG). Harder to fake than extension
File that is valid in multiple formats (e.g. valid GIF and valid PHP script) to bypass filters
System behavior depends on timing of events. (e.g. Time-of-check to Time-of-use TOCTOU)
Time Of Check to Time Of Use. A resource changes state between checking it (permission) and using it (writing)
Flaw in design of application logic (e.g. buying item for negative price, skipping payment step). Not a generic bug like SQLi

q: Can scanners find Business Logic bugs?
o: Rarely. They require understanding the business rules (context). Best found by manual testing/threat modeling
Manipulating data sent to server (URL params, form fields, cookies) to change app behavior (price=0)
Modifying cookie values to bypass auth or impersonate users (if not signed/encrypted)
Writing more data to a buffer than it can hold, overwriting adjacent memory. Leads to crash or code execution

q: Are managed languages (Java, Python) vulnerable to Buffer Overflow?
o: Generally No. Runtime handles memory safety. But native modules (C/C++) used by them can be vulnerable
Program fails to release memory, eventually consuming all RAM (DoS)
Arithmetic operation exceeds max value of integer type, wrapping around to min value (negative). Logic bug
User input passed as format string to `printf` (C). Can read/write memory ( `%x`, `%n`)
Injecting LDAP statements into input to alter LDAP queries (authentication bypass, info disclosure)
Injecting queries into NoSQL DB (MongoDB). e.g. passing `{ $ne: null }` to bypass password check
Executing OS commands via vulnerable app (e.g. app calls `ping $input`. input = `127.0.0.1; cat /etc/passwd`)
Attacker injects template syntax (e.g. `{{7*7}}`) which server renders. Can lead to RCE
Attacker injects template syntax into client-side framework (AngularJS sandboxing). Leads to XSS
Injecting HTML to overwrite global variables (window properties) by naming elements `id='foo'`. Confuses logic
Modifying `Object.prototype` in JS to affect all objects. Can bypass checks or lead to XSS/RCE
Freeze prototype `Object.freeze()`, use `Map` instead of Object, use library protection
Phishing attack. Page opened via `target='_blank'` controls opener via `window.opener.location`. Redirects original tab to fake login
Site redirects to URL parameter without validation (`example.com/login?next=evil.com`). Phishing vector
Attacker manipulates `Host` header. If app trusts it for generating links/reset emails, leads to cache poisoning or password reset hijacking
Discrepancy in how frontend (LB) and backend parse HTTP request (CL.TE vs TE.CL). Attacker 'smuggles' request to backend
Content-Length (Frontend) vs Transfer-Encoding (Backend). Frontend uses Length, Backend uses Chunked
Transfer-Encoding (Frontend) vs Content-Length (Backend). Frontend uses Chunked, Backend uses Length
Attacker tricks cache (CDN/Browser) into storing a malicious response (e.g. corrupted JS) serving it to other users
Attacker tricks user into visiting URL that looks static (`/profile/me.css`) but returns dynamic data. CDN caches private data
Targeting less secure elements in the supply network (e.g. dependency library, build server) to compromise final product
Registering domains/packages similar to popular ones (`react` vs `reacct`) to trick users
Publishing malicious public package with same name as private internal package. Managers might pull public (higher version)
Secrets (keys/creds) scattered across code, wikis, chat logs, unprotected buckets
Storing password directly in source code. Very bad practice. Easily found by static analysis
Vendor-supplied password (`admin/admin`). Attackers try these first. Must be changed on install
Trying a few common passwords against MANY accounts (avoids lockout)
Trying MANY passwords against ONE account (triggers lockout)
Brute force using a list of likely words/passwords (dictionary)
Spamming user with MFA push notifications until they approve out of annoyance/habit

Pointing a subdomain (CNAME) to a service (Heroku/AWS) that is no longer claimed. Attacker claims it and serves content

Vulnerability in CGI apps where `Proxy` header from client overwrites internal proxy config. Leads to MITM

Compression Ratio Info-leak Made Easy. Similar to BREACH but focuses on TLS compression (mostly fixed now)
Generating fake clicks on ads to steal revenue or drain budget
Users using same password across multiple sites. One breach compromises all
Threat from within organization (employee/contractor). Malicious or accidental
Granting only minimum permissions necessary. Fundamental security principle
Dividing tasks so no single person has full control (e.g. one dev writes code, another approves deploy)
Tools/strategies to prevent sensitive data from leaving network (detecting credit cards in email)
Encrypting data stored on disk/db (AES-256). Protects against physical theft of drive
Encrypting data moving over network (HTTPS/TLS). Protects against MITM
Only sender and receiver can read message. Server/Platform CANNOT read it (Signal, WhatsApp)

Same key used for encryption and decryption (AES). Fast, but key exchange is hard
Pair of keys (Public/Private). Public encrypts, Private decrypts (RSA, ECC). Slower

Increased complexity/surface area. Inconsistent policies across providers (AWS vs Azure)
Employees using unauthorized software/devices (e.g. personal Dropbox) putting data at risk

General Data Protection Regulation. EU law on data privacy. Heavy fines for breaches
Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard. Standards for handling credit card info
Audit report evaluating organization's information systems relevant to security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, privacy
International standard for Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)
Integrating security practices/culture into DevOps process (Development + Security + Operations)

q: What is 'Insecure Direct Object Reference' (IDOR) mitigation?
o: Access Control Checks! Check `if (record.owner == currentUser)` on EVERY access. Do not rely on obfuscated IDs (UUIDs help but aren't access control)
No. It prevents enumeration (guessing next ID), but if attacker GETS a UUID (via leak), they can access it unless Access Control is enforcing ownership

q: What is 'Mass Assignment' risk in Rails/Laravel?
o: By default, `User.create(params)` might set `is_admin` if it's in the payload. Must use `strong_parameters` or `$fillable`

o: Attacker sends 10 requests simultaneously. All read 'count=0' before any write 'count=1'. All succeed. (Fix: Database transactions/locks)
Attacker calls function, which calls back into attacker's code, which calls original function again BEFORE first call updates balance. Drains funds
Sending same parameter twice `?user=A&user=B`. App might use first, WAF might check second. Bypass WAF
Injecting CRLF (`%0d%0a`) into header values. Server interprets as end of header, starting body or new response. (e.g. Cache Poisoning)

Unauthorized transfer of data FROM a computer (stealing data)
Encoding stolen data in DNS queries (e.g. `secretdata.attacker.com`). Firewall allows DNS usually. Slow but effective
Hiding data within other data (e.g. hiding secret message bits inside pixels of an image)
Malicious code inserted intentionally that executes only when specific conditions are met (e.g. employee terminated)

Publicly releasing private identifying information about an individual (address, phone) as harassment
Prank call to emergency services to dispatch armed police (SWAT) to victim's home. Dangerous
Unskilled attacker using pre-made tools/scripts written by others

Combination of Red (Attack) and Blue (Defense) teams working together maximizing learning
Proactive search for malware/attackers lurking in network that evaded automated defenses
Decoy system designed to attract and trap attackers to study them or detect breach
Decoy file/token. If accessed/used, it alerts defenders (like canary in coal mine)
Service designed to delay/stall incoming connections (slow responses) to waste attacker's time/resources
Physically isolating secure network from unsecured networks (Internet). No cable connection
Enclosure blocking electromagnetic fields (preventing wireless signals in/out)
Rogue Wi-Fi access point mimicking a legitimate one (e.g. 'Starbucks Wi-Fi') to intercept traffic
Unauthorized AP installed on a network (by employee or attacker), creating backdoor
Driving around locating open Wi-Fi networks
Attack via public USB charging port. USB transfers power AND data. Compromised port can install malware
Device that blocks data pins on USB, allowing only charging. Prevents Juice Jacking
Unauthorized use of victim's computer to mine cryptocurrency (JS in browser or malware)
Injecting malicious JS into e-commerce checkout pages to steal credit card details (Magecart)
Formjacking. Online equivalent of physical card skimmer
Stealing tiny amounts (fractions of cent) from many transactions. Unnoticed individually
Infecting a website frequently visited by target group (e.g. dev forum) to compromise them
Doppelganger omits dot (e.g. `com` instead of `.com` in email). `admin@companycom` vs `admin@company.com`
Domain containing target name + keyword (`paypal-secure.com`). Very effective for phishing
Bot designed to extract content/data from websites
Bots performing malicious acts (credential stuffing, scraping prices, DDoS)
Bots performing useful acts (Googlebot crawler, Uptime monitor)
File telling well-behaved bots which pages NOT to crawl. Not a security mechanism (bad bots ignore it)
Relying on secrecy of design/implementation for security. Bad practice. (Design should be secure even if known)
A cryptosystem should be secure even if everything about the system, except the key, is public knowledge
Sum of all points (vectors) where an attacker can try to enter/extract data. Goal: Reduce it
Specific path/method used by attacker (e.g. Phishing email, SQLi field)
Exploit takes advantage of vulnerability. Payload is the code exploit delivers/runs (e.g. ransomware)
Probability of Threat exploiting Vulnerability x Impact. (Risk = Threat x Vuln x Impact)
Process of handling security breach (Preparation, Detection, Containment, Eradication, Recovery, Lessons Learned)
Investigation and analysis of evidence after cybercrime (preserving digital evidence)
Documentation showing who held/controlled evidence at every step. Crucial for legal validity
Adhering to laws/standards (GDPR, PCI-DSS). Minimum bar, not equal to Security
Independent review of system/records to verify compliance/security
Information about current threats/actors (IoCs, TTPs) used to inform defense
Indicator of Compromise. Artifact indicating breach (File hash, IP address, Domain)
Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures. Attacker's behavior patterns
Isolated environment for running untrusted code safely. (Browser sandbox, VM)
Breaking out of container isolation to access host OS (e.g. mounting docker socket, privileged mode)

q: What is 'Privileged Mode' risk in Docker?
o: Grants container full root capabilities of host. If compromised, host is compromised. AVOID in prod
Running security agent (proxy/log shipper) in separate container within same pod (K8s). Decouples security logic from app logic
Dividing network into tiny zones (down to workload level) to limit lateral movement. Central to Zero Trust
Attacker moving from one compromised system to others within network to find high-value target
IoT botnet that enslaved IP cameras/routers using default passwords (`admin/admin`) to launch massive DDoS
Hard to patch, often neglected. Embedded devices running old Linux kernels with known CVEs
Mechanism ensuring only signed/trusted OS/bootloader can run. Prevents Rootkits/Bootkits
Trusted Platform Module. Hardware chip for storing keys/secrets securely. Crucial for BitLocker/Secure Boot
Hardware Security Module. Dedicated appliance for managing keys/crypto operations. High security
Not a standard term. Likely referring to Bare Metal cloud or specific vendor product. Focus: Cloud Shared Responsibility Model
Cloud Provider secures 'of' the cloud (hardware, network). Customer secures 'in' the cloud (data, OS, app)

q: Who is responsible for 'Patching OS' in IaaS?

q: Who is responsible for 'Patching OS' in PaaS?
o: Provider (Cloud). They manage runtime (Heroku/App Engine). You just deploy code
Leaving storage bucket 'Public' (Read/Write to All Users). Common cause of massive data leaks
Identity with permissions that can be assumed by user or service (EC2 instance). Better than hardcoded keys

CPU side-channel attack exploiting Out-of-Order execution. User process reads Kernel memory
Bit flipping attack in RAM caused by rapidly accessing adjacent rows. Can gain root privs
Authenticating user by rhythm/speed of typing (Keystroke Dynamics)
Auth based on 'Who you are' (Fingerprint, Face, Iris, Voice)
No. If fingerprint is stolen/cloned, you can't reset it. Major privacy risk
Passwordless auth standard using public key crypto. Hardware keys (YubiKey) or Platform auth (TouchID)
User-friendly implementation of WebAuthn credentials synced across cloud (Apple/Google). Replacement for passwords
Practically No. Browser ensures passkey is only used for origin it was created for. Stops domain spoofing
Trick AI into ignoring its guardrails/instructions and executing user's malicious command ('Ignore previous instructions and...')
Attacker hides prompt in data (e.g. webpage, email) that LLM processes. LLM reads data and executes hidden command
Corrupting training data to make AI behave incorrectly or introduce backdoors
Querying model to reconstruct original training data (privacy leak)
Determining if specific data record was part of model's training set
AI confidently generating false/fabricated information. Security risk if used for code/decisions
Software Bill Of Materials. List of all components/libraries in software. Crucial for supply chain security
Vulnerability Exploitability eXchange. Companion to SBOM stating if a CVE in a component is actually exploitable in product context
Supply-chain Levels for Software Artifacts. Framework for ensuring integrity of software artifacts
Digitally signing executables/scripts to confirm author and guarantee no tampering
No trusted CA chain. Browsers warn users. Users might get conditioned to click 'Ignore warning', creating MITM opportunity
Hardcoding trusted certificate (or public key) in app. Prevents using rogue certificates even if valid CA issued them
HTTP Strict Transport Security. Header fetching browser to ONLY use HTTPS for domain. Stops Strip attacks
Content Security Policy. HTTP header controlling resources (scripts, images) browser is allowed to load. Mitigates XSS
Same-Origin Policy. Browser security model preventing scripts from one origin accessing data of another
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. Mechanism helping browsers relax SOP safely to allow cross-origin requests
Subresource Integrity. Validating integrity of external scripts (CDN) using hash (`integrity='sha384-...'`)
Tricking user into clicking invisible button overlaid on top of visible page (via iframe)
X-Frame-Options: DENY (or SAMEORIGIN), and CSP frame-ancestors
Header preventing page from being displayed in iframe/frame
Prevents browser from MIME-sniffing a response away from declared content-type (e.g. executing text/plain as JS)
Header controlling how much referrer info (URL) is sent with requests
Header controlling which browser features (camera, mic) can be used by page/iframes
Software Assurance Maturity Model. Framework to measure and improve software security activities
Application Security Verification Standard. Detailed list of security requirements and verification criteria
Card game to help dev teams identify security requirements (Threat Modeling gamification)
Intentionally insecure web application for security training/demos
Another deliberately insecure web app for training (Java based)
Damn Vulnerable Web App. PHP/MySQL web app for practicing exploits
Common Vulnerability Scoring System. Standard for rating severity of vulnerabilities (0-10)
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures. List of publicly known cybersecurity vulnerabilities (ID: CVE-2023-1234)
Common Weakness Enumeration. Categorization of software weaknesses (types of bugs)
National Vulnerability Database (US). Database of CVEs with analysis/scoring
Program where companies pay independent researchers for reporting valid security bugs
Researcher reports bug privately to vendor, giving them time to fix before publishing details
Publishing all details of vulnerability immediately (sometimes used to pressure vendor if they ignore reports)
Vulnerability known to attackers but unknown to vendor (0 days to fix). High value
Toolkit automating exploitation of client-side vulnerabilities (browsers/plugins)
Unintended download of malware just by visiting a compromised website (no click needed)
Malicious Advertising. Injecting malware into legitimate ad networks
Systematic approach to identifying/rating threats to a system (STRIDE, DREAD)
Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege
Risk rating model: Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected Users, Discoverability
Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis. Risk-centric threat modeling
Threat modeling specifically for Privacy (Linkability, Identifiability, Non-repudiation, Detectability, Disclosure, Unawareness, Non-compliance)
Diagram showing possible attacks against a target in a tree structure (Root = Goal, Leaves = Methods)
Simulation of real-world attack by authorized group to test effectiveness of defenses
Defensive team responsible for detecting and responding to attacks
Authorized simulated cyberattack on computer system to evaluate security (Specific scope)
Tester has no prior knowledge of target system (External perspective)
Tester has full knowledge (source code, diagrams) of target system
Tester has partial knowledge (e.g. user credentials but no source code)
Automated process of identifying known vulnerabilities (Nessus, Qualys)
Tool reports a vulnerability that does not exist
Tool fails to report a vulnerability that DOES exist (Dangerous)
Tool correctly identifies a real vulnerability
Tool correctly reports no vulnerability when there is none
Knowing what you have (servers, software, data). You can't protect what you don't know you have
Center for Internet Security Controls. Prioritized set of actions to protect organsations
Safeguard or countermeasure to avoid/minimize risk (Administrative, Physical, Technical)
Stops attack from happening (Firewall blocking port)
Alternative control used when primary control isn't feasible (e.g. WAF instead of patching legacy app)
Comparing current state to desired state (standards/goals) to find missing pieces
Not just finding bugs, but prioritizing remediation based on risk to business
High-level overview for non-technical stakeholders (Impact, Cost, risk dashboard)
Step-by-step reproduction steps for developers to fix issues
Checking if remediation was successful and didn't introduce new bugs
Risk remaining after controls are applied (No system is 100% secure)
Management decision to accept risk (cost of fix > cost of loss)
Eliminating activity causing risk (Stop using legacy feature)
Routine practices to maintain health of system (Updates, pw changes, backups)
Security mechanisms should not be too difficult for users, or they will bypass them
Measures that look secure but provide little real protection (e.g. annoying password rules)
Broken Object Level Authorization. Attacker accesses other user's object by changing ID in API call (Same as IDOR)
Broken Function Level Authorization. Non-admin calls admin API endpoint due to missing check
Exposing old API versions (v1) or dev endpoints that lack security controls
Security of Lambda/Functions. Risks include event-data injection, increasing costs (Denial of Wallet), permission sprawl
Causing huge cloud bill by triggering auto-scaling resource consumption (DDoS on Pay-per-use)
Escaping container to host. Same as Docker Escape
Scanning Terraform/CloudFormation files for misconfigurations (Public buckets) before deploy
Kubernetes Security Posture Management. Tools to secure K8s clusters
Cloud Security Posture Management. Tools monitoring cloud config (AWS/Azure) for violations
Cloud Workload Protection Platform. Protection for instances/containers (AV, HIDS)
Cloud Native Application Protection Platform. Unified platform combining CSPM, CWPP, etc
Security model: 'Never Trust, Always Verify'. No distinct 'internal' trusted network. Every request auth'd/encrypted

q: What is 'Lateral Movement' in Zero Trust?
o: Prevented! Because authenticating to one service doesn't automatically grant access to others

q: What is 'VPN' usage in Zero Trust?
o: Replaced by per-app access (SDP - Software Defined Perimeter). User connects to App, not Network
Just-In-Time access. Granting permissions only when needed, for limited time, then revoking
Emergency admin account used only when normal auth fails (e.g. IDP down). Highly monitored
